Come, your answer in broken music; for thy voice is music and thy English broken; therefore, queen of all, Katherine, break thy mind to me in broken English—wilt thou have me?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Dat is as it shall please de roi mon père.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Nay, it will please him well, Kate; it shall please him, Kate.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Den it sall also content me.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Upon that I kiss your hand, and I call you my queen.

line.french: Laissez, mon seigneur, lais sez, laissez! Ma foi, je ne veux point que vous abaissez votre grandeur en baisant la main d’une (Notre Seigneur!) indigne serviteur. Excusez-moi, je vous supplie, mon très puissant seigneur.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Then I will kiss your lips, Kate.

line.french: Les dames et demoiselles pour être baisées devant leur noces, il n’est pas la coutume de France.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Madam my interpreter, what says she?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Dat it is not be de fashon pour les ladies of France—I cannot tell wat is baiser en Anglish.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: To kiss.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Your Majestee entendre bettre que moi.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: It is not a fashion for the maids in France to kiss before they are married, would she say?

line.french: Oui, vraiment.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: O Kate, nice customs cur’sy to great kings. Dear Kate, you and I cannot be confin’d within the weak list of a country’s fashion. We are the makers of manners, Kate; and the liberty that follows our places stops the mouth of all find-faults, as I will do yours, for upholding the nice fashion of your country in denying me a kiss; therefore patiently and yielding.

You have witchcraft in your lips, Kate; there is more eloquence in a sugar touch of them than in the tongues of the French council; and they should sooner persuade Harry of England than a general petition of monarchs. Here comes your father.

scene.stagedir: Enter the French Power and the English Lords.

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: God save your Majesty! My royal cousin, teach you our princess English?

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: I would have her learn, my fair cousin, how perfectly I love her, and that is good English.

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: Is she not apt?

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Our tongue is rough, coz, and my condition is not smooth; so that having neither the voice nor the heart of flattery about me, I cannot so conjure up the spirit of love in her, that he will appear in his true likeness.

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: Pardon the frankness of my mirth, if I answer you for that. If you would conjure in her, you must make a circle; if conjure up Love in her in his true likeness, he must appear naked and blind. Can you blame her then, being a maid yet ros’d over with the virgin crimson of modesty, if she deny the appearance of a naked blind boy in her naked seeing self? It were, my lord, a hard condition for a maid to consign to.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Yet they do wink and yield, as love is blind and enforces.

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: They are then excus’d, my lord, when they see not what they do.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Then, good my lord, teach your cousin to consent winking.

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: I will wink on her to consent, my lord, if you will teach her to know my meaning; for maids, well summer’d and warm kept, are like flies at Bartholomew-tide, blind, though they have their eyes, and then they will endure handling, which before would not abide looking on.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: This moral ties me over to time and a hot summer; and so I shall catch the fly, your cousin, in the latter end, and she must be blind too.

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: As love is, my lord, before it loves.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: It is so; and you may, some of you, thank love for my blindness, who cannot see many a fair French city for one fair French maid that stands in my way.

speech.speaker: FR. KING.
speech.line: Yes, my lord, you see them perspectively: the cities turn’d into a maid; for they are all girdled with maiden walls that war hath never ent’red.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Shall Kate be my wife?

speech.speaker: FR. KING.
speech.line: So please you.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: I am content, so the maiden cities you talk of may wait on her; so the maid that stood in the way for my wish shall show me the way to my will.

speech.speaker: FR. KING.
speech.line: We have consented to all terms of reason.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Is’t so, my lords of England?

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: The King hath granted every article:
His daughter first; and in sequel, all,
According to their firm proposed natures.

speech.speaker: EXE.
speech.line: Only he hath not yet subscribed this:

Where your Majesty demands that the King of France, having any occasion to write for matter of grant, shall name your Highness in this form, and with this addition, in French, Notre très cher fils Henri, Roi d’Angleterre, Héritier de France; and thus in Latin, Praeclarissimus filius noster Henricus, Rex Angliae, et Heres Franciae.

speech.speaker: FR. KING.
speech.line: Nor this I have not, brother, so denied,
But your request shall make me let it pass.

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: I pray you then, in love and dear alliance,
Let that one article rank with the rest,
And thereupon give me your daughter.

speech.speaker: FR. KING.
speech.line: Take her, fair son, and from her blood raise up
Issue to me, that the contending kingdoms
Of France and England, whose very shores look pale
With envy of each other’s happiness,
May cease their hatred; and this dear conjunction
Plant neighborhood and Christian-like accord
In their sweet bosoms, that never war advance
His bleeding sword ’twixt England and fair France.

speech.speaker: LORDS.
speech.line: Amen!

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Now welcome, Kate; and bear me witness all,
That here I kiss her as my sovereign queen.

speech.speaker: Q. ISA.
speech.line: God, the best maker of all marriages,
Combine your hearts in one, your realms in one!
As man and wife, being two, are one in love,
So be there ’twixt your kingdoms such a spousal,
That never may ill office, or fell jealousy,
Which troubles oft the bed of blessed marriage,
Thrust in between the paction of these kingdoms,
To make divorce of their incorporate league;
That English may as French, French Englishmen,
Receive each other. God speak this Amen!

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Amen!

speech.speaker: K. HEN.
speech.line: Prepare we for our marriage; on which day,
My Lord of Burgundy, we’ll take your oath,
And all the peers’, for surety of our leagues.
Then shall I swear to Kate, and you to me,
And may our oaths well kept and prosp’rous be!

speech.speaker: CHORUS.
speech.line: Thus far, with rough and all-unable pen,
Our bending author hath pursu’d the story,
In little room confining mighty men,
Mangling by starts the full course of their glory.
Small time; but in that small most greatly lived
This star of England. Fortune made his sword;
By which the world’s best garden he achieved,
And of it left his son imperial lord.
Henry the Sixth, in infant bands crown’d King
Of France and England, did this king succeed;
Whose state so many had the managing,
That they lost France, and made his England bleed;
Which oft our stage hath shown; and for their sake,
In your fair minds let this acceptance take.
